reviewText:
Atom Zombie Smasher is a super little indie strategy game.  The basic premise is that you take on the guise of a commander holding back the zombie hordes from overruning your city.

It works on two levels; first is the strategy where a map of the city districts is where you see the progress of zombie infestations and plan your next mission.  You can choose which military assets you take with you from: infantry, snipers, mines, demolitions, barricades, gas attracting teams or artillery.  Once you initiate the mission, the game changes to a tactical sub-game where you place your units on the map to best protect the civilians you are trying to extract from the map, while avoiding collateral damage.  To many dead civilians and you fail.

There are a number of tactical elements that affect each mission type such as: map layout, dangerous area which can explode if you are not careful, more or less time-limit & available/unavailable units.

You win if you extract a minimum number of civilians or your units are able to destroy the encroaching zed hordes.  However if you do not clear the map of zeds before nightfall more zeds arrive to swarm the map.  Successful missions reward you with points that go towards an overall victory target.  Units also receive XP to increase their unique zed destroying abilities and they can level up to increase those abilites to make them more clincial.

The zeds then receive strategic points allocated to some city district (1-4) which determines the strength of the zombie hordes and the difficulty of initiating a mission there.  This continues until you reach the campaign victory target.

Though gameplay is fairly repetitive the addition of custom campaign options make the strategy and tactical aspects that much more varied.  Scientists can be found wondering the city area and can be rescued.  Each one can then be spent" to acquire research upgrades towards 8 specific areas of interest including: faster xp gains for units
hoursPlayed: more destructive weapons etc).  You can have access to strategic and tactical weapons that can clear zeds from an entire district thus reseting the danger level there.  Just be aware of the monster-zeds! lol\n\nFor me this was a surprise gem of a game.  While graphics are just basic sprites

reviewText:
A top down view of the Zombie Apocalypse!

Great soundtrack and effects coupled with addictive gameplay make this a surprising hit for what is a basic top down 2d game with sprites.  Kind of like a tower defense game, but without a fixed base - the people you save are essentially what you are trying to protect!

The Campaign map or strategic view is where you begin.  Every turn zombies (Zeds) take over new territories. From these you choose a territory/city to attempt to rescue civilians from.  This will launch your team deployment phase - placing helicopter landing point etc.

Once each turn or rescue begins, you have a set number of people you have to rescue to be successful - should you fail to hit this number, you will lose that territory.  Should you succeed, it will become neutral.  Rescue during missions is achieved by clicking with the mouse to adjust landing zone for your helicopter in a way that draws the people away from the edges of the city where the Zeds emerge from.  During the daytime when rescue missions begin, this will be from marked entrances, but on sun down, more Zeds will appear from all edges of the city!!

Only people within a certain radius hear the helicopters horn and move towards it - which can later be upgrade - there is a delay until the helicopter arrives and how many people it can carry which you can also be upgraded as you progress.  You unlock new units to assist you as the campaign progresses such as mobile soldier squad, fixed artillery which you can place on a rooftop, sniper team and roadblocks to name a few.

The Zed get scored on how many people they 'convert' regardless of the outcome.  At the end of the mission you are returned to the main map, and scores are added up for yourself and the zed.  At set points totals fixed events occur, such as 'Giant Zeds' etc to spice things up a bit.  Also, depending upon the month/turn, Zed will invade other territories.  The ultimate aim being to out-score the zed in what is essentially a points race - for a large part of which you will be behind in until you discover 'Llama bombs' later in the game ;-)


Overall it is a great little addictive strategy game, one word of warning though, it only has the one soundtrack, so if you don't like it, you may want to turn the music off altogether!

reviewText:
The brand of near-impossible challenge this game offers is not to my taste. There is undoubtedly a way to beat it, but several things I prefer to have direct control over are never in the player's hands to begin with.

Atom Zombie Smasher focues on rescueing civilians from zones infested with zombies. You have no control over the civilians on the ground; you can only send an evacuation helicoptor and hope all the civilians get to it in time. In order to aid you in this mission, you are given control of a random set of resources.

These resources are randomized for every mission, and it is this aspect to the game that I cannot stand. Sometimes you'll have access to attack dogs and snipers, other times you'll have mines and blockades. Rarely, all you'll have access to is blockades and a paltry 3 bombs with which to stem the zombie tide. Even worse, the challenges you'll face vary from times of day (fewer zombies in sunshine, etc) to superzombies that require a considerable effort to take down.

Every zone you lose to the zombies gets chalked up on a big scoreboard. First to a set score wins, and it's an uphill battle for any player from the start. If I had control over my resources, I might enjoy this. However, I don't so I can't.

reviewText:
Who remembers this one? Back from the olden days of Winter Sale coal and fresh indie zombie games. Actually, maybe it's more appropriate to ask if you remember that decade-old zombie simulator with the colored dots, because this is the fully gameified version of that. Humanity is on the retreat from the zombie hordes and it's up to you to evacuate the survivors from your region. You can select different infested areas from the strategic map based on the infection level (difficulty), and it takes you to a small city map where you have to plan the evacuation. You get a helicopter that airlifts folks (yellow dots) out every 20 seconds or so, and up to 3 mercenary units to help defend. These units are anything from soldiers and snipers to landmines and barricades. After each mission you AND the zombies get victory points based on the final number of survivors and zombies. New events occur as you both reach certain victory point milestones, and the first side to rack up the target number of points wins.

Sounds solid, right? Unfortunately, this all comes together to form a strategy game that's mostly based on random chance. Just like the old simulator, humans turn into zombies instantly when touched, and you better believe the survivors clump up around the landing zones like delicious stuffing. All it takes is one zombie escaping your best-laid deathtrap to ruin an entire map. This is further exacerbated by the fact that your 3 mercenary units are randomized for each mission. So while you're in good shape if you get your mortars and zombie baits in one mission, you're boned if you get stuck with barricades, mines, and bombs, all of which are one-use tricks. There's also random variance in the performance of your units; soldiers can miss, and your mortars can go off-target, ruining that hail mary shot you needed to save the day. There are a host of other frustrations, like how you and the zombies get points for holding territory, but you only claim territory if you kill ALL the zombies on the map before sundown, which is ludicrously difficult even if you have the right mercs for it.

It's a shame, too, because the presentation is stylish and weird, and there are some neat systems to explore like XP to improve your mercs and rescuing scientists to upgrade your other abilities. The story vignettes are compellingly strange as well and I still can't make heads or tails of the story, but I know Tesla and an antichrist baby are involved. Shame I'll never figure it out, because the game's just too damn discouraging and frustrating to get through.

I've read a lot of good things about this game and I've read a lot of bad things about this game so I tried to keep an open mind going in. I personally think the game fundamentals are solid, but you have to look past the cheesy graphics. The overall impression I get is Risk meets Choplifter with minimal tower defense and real time strategy elements.\n\nThere is technically no way to win--there are only degrees of losing. The goal is to rescue as many non-infected as you can or destroy the zombie hordes before nightfall. You are given a basic assortment of mercenaries for offensive purposes which level up as they gain experience, and it's only after they start leveling that the game's fun factor is uncovered; just watch out for the friendly fire! Achievements are always a plus. The price tag is a bit on the heavy side for my expectations, but it would be wise to download the demo and judge for yourself. Overall, I found it to be a refreshing distraction.

2011 was an amazing year for PC games. Sadly, this means a few great titles have been overlooked amidst the flurry of releases. Atom Zombie Smasher is the best of them. Developer Brandon Chung has always been a master of style - even his student game Barista 2 has more spunk than most commercial releases - and in Atom Zombie Smasher that style really meshes with the gameplay. The randomly-selected narrative vignettes are amusing, but this is a game that tells its story almost entirely through its gameplay. This is a real, horrifying zombie apocalypse, viewed with a clinical distance. You will try and save Nuevo Aires. You will lose. And you'll enjoy it all the way.

Sometimes, you must slaughter a few cows to save the herd, and in this game some deliberate collateral damage will be a virtual necessity.\nBasically, you fly out to a bunch of rather urban-looking towns populated by civvies (yellow dots), where zombies (purple dots) start pouring in from the outskirts. You, from a high-flying bird's-eye view, direct efforts to airlift the civvies the heck out of there while using snipers, commandos, barricades, dynamite, mortar fire, and more to hold back or redirect the tide of zombies. Infection spreads FAST, and there's no penalty for getting a little, uh, extreme with your methods, so... yeah. Sledgehammers for nails. If you're quick, you can blow up all the zombies and win that way, too.\nThere's also a strategy element where you choose upgrades for your troops, direct research focus, and pick which town to try to evacuate based on your current (random) assignment of weaponry and tools. Still, the meat of the game is evacuating towns.
From the moment you start, it is clear that this game smashes the Tower Defence concept into something bizarrely unique. Also, there is plenty of Surf Rock.

A seamless blend of tactical strategy and minimalist storytelling with underlying ethical quandaries.

A lone zombie corners a pack of citizens--do you strike pre-emptively, bombarding the area with artillery fire in order to deny the Zed those precious victory points? Do you wait for the plague to spread so your soldiers can reap the experience from killing those undead? Or do you gamble the lives of innocents on your snipers' aim speed?

Randomized city layouts and rotating mercenary teams keep each mission fresh and exciting; settings offer total control over each game to adjust the difficulty wherever you choose; modding is simple, yet suitable for full overhauls of the mechanics; vignettes offer brief but telling glimpses into characters that may not appear in gameplay but make up a key part of the world.

Highly recommended.

Atom Zombie Smasher is a strategy game where you defeat the zombie invasion by repelling  or destroying hordes of zombies as they close in on the survivors you're trying to rescue.

The game has an overworld campaign, where you try to prevent the zombies from spreading out of control, and the city section, where you kill lots of zombies. The overworld plays a bit like Risk. The city sections play very differently depending on what weapons you have available, and this is random. If you have artillery and snipers, it's not too hard to annihilate the zombies quickly. If you have roadblocks and bait, then you need to get everyone out quickly.

I've definitely enjoyed it so far. The biggest flaws are its weak tutorial and the fact that a bad choice of random weapons might force you to concede a map. But, the strategy's good and it's fun to play. I haven't tried the local co-op yet... seems fun though.

If you like strategy games, I think this is worth picking up, but your milage may vary.

I would give Atom Zombie Smasher a 6/10. It is a bird's eye view zombie evacuation game, with qualities of a tower defense game.

Your goal is to evacuate citizens from various citeis of a country during a zombie outbreak. The more citizens you save, the higher your score and the more upgrades you can unlock. You have multiple weapons and tools available at your disposal to use, though these are randomly assigned to you. This is because, in my eyes, you have an entire country to defend and evacuate, as the zombies spread at an alarming rate (go figure: they are zombies) and the situation can quickly turn very bad.

I found the game to be very strategic in certain instances, and less so in others. This winds up being the best strength and worst weakness of the game at the same time. When given random sets of gear, sometimes you are underpowered and stand little hope, sometimes you are given overpowered ones and it is too easy (you can sometimes have a weapon set that lets you airstrike the entire city, once you upgrade them enough: how fun and challenging), and sometimes you have a set where it is possible to succeed, but forces you to think, plan, and change tactics mid game. This is when it is at its most fun.

You are able to set up a customized game if you wish, to add further challenge and some replayability. In the end though, Atom Zombie Shasher is not a long term game. It is one to play for a bit, then uninstall, then come back to on occasion once you are itching to try again.

I recommend this game as long as you know are aware of that fact. Atom Zombie Smasher has a very limited way to play it, but it sure is fun for the first few times you do it. Approaching the situation as if you were actually evacuating cities from a zombie outbreak is pretty fun, and you definitely can't save everyone which adds an element of realism to a very goofy game. Don't expect to play it for 20+ hours or anything, but as a once in a while game it does its job very well. If you can find it in a humble bundle or on sale for a buck or two, it is definitely worth it.

One way of describing Atom Zombie Smasher is to call it a real time strategy game...but I think that this still fails to fully describe the experience of playing Atom Zombie Smasher....
You play as a commander who must save civilians, exterminate zombies and rid the area of Nuevos Aires of the zombie infestation in a world set in the 1960's. You are scored based on how many civilians you rescue, how many zombies you kill and how quickly you achieve this.
The storyline campaign features a map of Nuevos Aires divided into regions (the number of regions can be edited according to how long you want to play for or what target score you set). Regions are coloured according to whether they are infested with zombies, have been liberated by you or have had all the life bombed out of them. Regions are also numbered to show the extent of zombie infestation, with higher numbers indicating a larger number of zombies to kill.
You have access to a helicopter (which airlifts people to safety) and then attack units to use to help you kill zombies. Attack units include ground infantry, snipers, dynamite, road blocks, etc, but you can only use 4 attack units at a time. Once you have chosen a region, you launch into a square map with randomly placed buildings, roads and civilians. You will be shown where zombies will approach from and asked to place your units on the map in strategically chosen locations. When you're done, you watch as the zombies move in and the level commences. You can move a few units after placing them, but not for most of them, so you have to really think hard about where you put them.
There are comic book style cutscenes which appear randomly and explain the game's backstory. The cutscenes have a certain brand of dark humour which I find hilarious, but some people might not appreciate.
You can also adjust game settings to make things easier or harder depending on what you want to get out of the game. For example, you can start out with all attack units, allow zombies to spawn inside a region, allow mega zombies, etc.
Overall, this is a game worth looking at if you like strategy games.

You find yourself evacuating civilians in the form of yellow dots by helicopter in an urban theatre from a horde of zombies, or Zed, represented as pink-purple dots.  As the campaign progresses, you find your mission objectives evolving from evacuation to Zed elimination.

Blendo Games delivers a game that challenges your brain as you are concerned with concepts like Zed/Civilian routing and great timing to meet your mission objectives.

Although the overall campaign is solid, I was disappointed on the outcome.  You are presented the same ending whether you win or lose.  I feel as though there is little reward for actually winning the game short of giving yourself a soft pat on the back on close calls.  This leads to the lackluster of the replayability of Atom Zombie Smasher.  As you get better at the game, you may find the game too easy.  The parameters in the game you can set in the beginning of the game could spice things up but overall it's the same game, just way easier or way harder.

The cherry on the top to my recommendation is the price tag. When the game is on sell, you should grab it and give it a try.  You will find it was worth more than a burger at a fast food joint.  For a small brain game (a la Minesweeper) this game is fantastic.

Atom Zombie Smasher is a simple, yet fun, game about zombies and controlling flow. In it's own way it is very much a simple puzzler.

The game is divided into two areas. First there is the overworld map where land is divided into provinces for you to contest over with the zombie menace. Here you choose which area to send your mercenaries to infected provinces of varying difficulty (number of infected present) and, depending on the game settings you chose, choosing which mercenaries to send. Second is the battle map itself. Here you get to place where your rescue chopper will initally land and draw survivors towards it as well as other mercenaries in building around the map (artillery, snipers, etc) or deployed in the streets (foot soldiers, mines, dynamite, barricades, etc).

Mercenaries are all designed to help you control flow and rescue survivors and scientists from the infected zones. Helicopter for rescue, artillery, foot soldiers, snipers, barricades, mines and dynamite are all examples of some of the mercs you get to use. As you attain kills or successful rescue numbers each merc group will level up and be upgradeable. This generally comes down to faster movement, rate of fire, deployment or reduced loading times.

As the game progresses and you rescue more scientists you gain control of the 'Llama Cannon which allows for orbital bombardment of a zone every few provinces.

All in all the game is fun and can be addictive depending on your tastes.
Pick this up in a sale and you certainly won't regret it!

Atom Zombie Smasher (Steam) (Humble) from Blendo Games is a unique strategy game.  Zombies are invading the 1960s city of Nuevos Aires, and you are tasked with evacuating the populace from each district from your orbital platform.

Each month, you can take on one mission and try to rescue as many civilians as possible.  Everything is procedurally generated, from the city limits to the levels to even the names of your mercenary squadrons.

The city grid is full of little yellow cubes, which represent citizens.  Zombies will come pouring in from side streets in a wave of purple cubes.  If they touch a citizen, it will instantly be turned.  A sure-fire victory can be instantly turned to defeat by one lone zed wandering into a clump of defenseless people.  You’ll need to mitigate this risk by carefully deploying and directing your troops.

As the game goes on, you’ll receive new and interesting units to deploy, though you’ll only get a random assortment of them each round.  This keeps things challenging, as you can’t take on a completely infested level with just a single mortar.  You’ll need to decide each round how hard of a level you think you can complete with your ever-changing arsenal.  Your different units can level up and improve their capabilities, and you can even recruit scientists to give you some bonus powers.  The Llama bombs are especially game-changing.   You only have a set time to evacuate citizens before night falls and zeds come pouring in from every angle, almost ensuring any remaining citizens will die.  This puts a soft cap on the length of time a level can take; most will last 3 minutes or less.

Let’s talk about that music!  A handful of upbeat, cheerful tracks of what I would term “Beach Rock” add a layer of dissonance to the disturbing proceedings taking place below.  Jamming guitars and pounding drums make you so happy to be mowing down zombies and abandoning people to die just so you can save a few others!  But its OK, you’ll say, because they’re just cubes anyway.  They turn purple.  That’s a nice color.

The campaign mode offers a big list of customization options so you can set it to be as hard or as breezy as you’d like.  You can also remove some of the randomization and select your squads at the beginning of each month, which is a feature I really liked.  Oh, and there’s also a set of backstory vignettes you can collect to tell you about the history of Nuevos Aires and how the outbreak occurred.

A strange take on the zombie apocalypse and to an extent, on strategy games on the whole. From the game's surf soundtrack, to it's hokey comic vignetttes, to the ridiculous randomized names of your squads, to the foghorn of the rescue chopper, everything is a little off kilter. The thing is, this game has a lot going for it in my eyes. The gameplay is absolutely on point. From the macro boardgame map where every mission you do effects the spread of the zombies and how many points you gain towards overall campaign victory, to the micro boards, where every second your snipers can fire and every scientist you can rescue on a mission matters. The game has both a planning phase and an action phase. The planning phase takes place before the mission begins in full, and allows you to place all your units, some which you can move later, and some which you can't. You'll have to be careful though because they CAN be killed, and barriers can be avoided if a gas line ruptures and the following building collapse eliminates your chokepoint. Then, in the action phase, the zombies start flooding in, the chopper flies over, and you can start blowing things up with your artillery. The random city designs force you to think critically and adapt on every single level, and if you're playing with base game rules, the rotation of available squads will also force you to get good at more than one playstyle. I don't want to spoil too much, because I found a lot of the fun came in the surprises of the new challenges presented as the campaign progressed, and the new troops and comics you unlock while playing. I really respect what was done with the base game, but if you don't like it, you can change pretty much any setting you could think of, and if not, there's a simple ingame mod system which can change even more stuff, if you like. Altogether pretty brilliant, and if nothing else, you should really try the demo for a sample and to check that it runs well on your PC. 8.5/10 because of how refreshing and exciting it was.

Description: A top-down real-time strategy game (with unlimited planning stage) in which the player must rescue civilians by helicopter from zombies entering by several points surrounding the map. The player places units, barricades, and explosives in the planning stage, then during the real-time portion maneuvers/uses them in order to slow the zombies from reaching the civilians before they can be rescued. As missions go by, the player acquires a larger arsenal, points with which to upgrade the various units, and new mission types. Zombie incursions increase in size and difficulty in discrete stages.

Is it playable? (Barely/Mostly/Completely)
Completely.

Bugs?
None.

User Interface?
Easy to use and straightforward.

How good is it? (Terrible/Bad/0k/Good/Great)
Good

Audio?
Satisfactory explosions, gunfire, sirens, etc. The music had a generally Latin feel. The audio enhanced the gaming experience.

Visuals?
Colorful art style. Comic-style drawings used to help convey story points. Game map visually basic, with zombies and units represented simply for maximum visibility. Not visually impressive.

Story?
Barely there. Your Mileage May Very whether that's a good or bad thing. Personally, I think zombie stories are usually silly, and so the lack of a more substantial treatment is no big loss and even opened room for player-driven narrative stemming from mechanical interaction during missions. Zombies happen. You defend against them and eventually destroy them entirely. 20 lines of story.

Mechanics?
Solid and varied enough for several hours of fun. Sometimes the random selection of units made available in the vanilla game proved frustrating, as it is impossible to win with some combinations. On the other hand, playing with certain of the non-vanilla boxes ticked made the game much too easy (especially the ability to select whichever units you want for every mission).

Recommend
